Mar 10

The growth mindset: engage your problems to move beyond them

(FYI, the next post in this series is here.)

Petra was born into wealth and power, and everybody–even her parents–did what she wanted. As an adult, she took over running her family’s businesses. She failed miserably.

An advisor told her, “Petra, you must negotiate with these people.” She taught Petra what she needed to know, and Petra did what her advisor said. But her efforts came to nothing because she still expected people to do what she wanted.

Why did Petra fail?

Her advisor’s techniques didn’t work because her viewpoint about how people behave sabotaged her actions.

Viewpoints and the growth mindset

In the area of personal development, Carol Dweck’s discovery of the growth mindset is the single most powerful idea of the last half century.

The growth mindset can be summarized as follows:

The growth mindset states that a person’s talents and abilities are not fixed at birth but can be enhanced by effort, learning, and persistence.

Dweck’s discovery has been validated by 40 years of research. To learn more, you can read my introductory article on the growth mindset.

Why are viewpoints useful?

Moving from the fixed mindset to the growth mindset is difficult because you need to suppress your natural impulses and learn to do the exact opposite.

Petra failed because her natural impulse was to tell people what to do.

She would have succeeded if she had reversed how she saw the world:

Other people won’t do things just because you tell them to, so you have to listen to what they want.

If Petra had adopted this viewpoint and acted accordingly, she would have been successful running her company.

What viewpoints support the growth mindset?

I have discovered seven separate viewpoints that you can use to move from a fixed to a growth mindset.

The viewpoints covered in the previous posts are the reality of the growth mindset, the cost of the fixed mindset, choice, effort, and failure.

The viewpoints that build on top of these deal with:

  • engagement
  • perseverance

And that leads us to:

Beat your problems down before they beat you up

Viewpoint 6: You understand that you will get better results by attacking your problems with energy and optimism, and by doing so sooner rather than later.

Here’s an important observation: The bigger the challenge, the bigger the jump forward when you engage and solve it. Understanding this will motivate you to get past each challenge.

And why not just jump in and tackle it right now? Doing so will preserve your momentum forward.

What you will gain

This viewpoint of engagement gives you four important benefits:

  • It decreases how much you are frightened and demoralized by the problems you encounter, and for how long
  • It motivates you to get past your problems, and to do so faster
  • It makes you feel good about yourself and your work
  • It strengthens your identity as a confident and effective person

When you adopt this viewpoint of engagement and act accordingly, you are living the growth mindset.

Dweck: [Students with the growth mindset] told us that they, too, sometimes felt overwhelmed, but their response was to dig in and do what it takes. They were like George Danzig…a graduate student in math at Berkeley.

One day, as usual, he rushed in late to his math class and quickly copied the two homework problems from the blackboard. When he later went to do them, he found them very difficult, and it took him several days of hard work to crack them open and solve them.

They turned out not to be homework problems at all. They were two famous math problems that had never been solved.

This post continues a series of six posts about the viewpoints that will make it easier for you to adopt the growth mindset. You can begin by reading the first post.

Originally published at greggwilliams.co.

Are you missing out?

Medium is brilliant, and I’m grateful to be published by The Coffeelicious. But there are several problems with this arrangement:

  • You may miss my articles if you aren’t looking at Medium all the time
  • Things change, and I may decide to publish my work elsewhere

If you’ve read this far, you already know that you can’t find what I offer — practical help from a therapist — anywhere else.

Subscribe to my newsletter and you will get every article delivered automatically to your inbox. I’ll never give your email address to anybody, and you can cancel at any time.

You’ll also get occasional “freebies” — like a mini-magazine PDF of this series on viewpoints and the growth mindset.

Click here to subscribe, and start leading a better life. Thanks!

— Gregg Williams, MFT
